metadata.title: Sebastian Maniscalco talks comedy, SNL impersonation and invisalign
metadata.author: ABC News

transcript: He's a well-known comedian, actor, and podcast host, and his massive It Ain't Right tour is selling out shows all across the country. Plus, he has a comedy special that starts streaming on Hulu tomorrow. ABC's Ashen Singh caught up with Sebastian Maniscalo. During Love Making, I'm getting I'm getting Charlie horses. This Do you ever have this happen? Right. Right in the middle. I'm like, "Oh god, get off. Oh my god, I can't I can't get rid of it, babe. I You're special. It's unbelievable, by the way. Thank you. It deals with the absurdities of society, from social media to getting older. I mean, Sebastian, what's grinding your gears these days? Uh, well, the special is called It Ain't Right. And as I look around, a lot of things ain't right. Here's one thing that's bothering me. People who wear Invisalign during the day. This should be at night, at night only. It's just I have a hard time not focusing on the saliva that gets caught between the the the the Invisalign and the teeth. So, yeah. I mean, listen, I made a living out of like uh talking about uh basically observational humor and things that kind of uh upset me. So, this special in particular not only deals with that, but like you said, getting older. I'm 52. I got a six-year-old and an eight-year-old, so I'm like an older father. And uh yeah, I'm just I'm just sore at the end of the day with the amount of bending that I have to do and I'm basically icing my knees at the end of the uh day. So yeah, it's uh I had a great time uh uh shooting this special in my hometown of Chicago. I'm looking forward to it airing on Friday. Yeah. You shot this special back in Chicago at the United Center. What was it like bringing the special back home? What did that mean to you? Yeah. So, it was my uh second special uh that I did in Chicago and uh performing at at home. It's just I don't know. It's very familiar to me. There's a lot of sarcasm in Chicago. Chicago really kind of uh molded me as a comedian growing up making fun of uh friends and whatnot. Even though when I go back to Chicago now, I get ripped to shreds. Right. There's Oh, man. I mean, there's no way I could have a big head with the amount of friends that I have that make fun of me. Uh, you know, they'll probably see this piece and go, "Uh, what were you wearing?" You know, it's it's just always just always a ra a razing we give each other. So, uh, it was great to do it there. Have my family there, my father, my my kids were there, my mother. Um, it was it was something special. You said before that you made the conscious decision to keep your material away from controversial topics and political issues. Do you think that uh hot button issues are something that comedians should avoid or is it just something that's not really your lane? Uh not my lane. I don't do politics. I feel that uh everybody's inundated with politics, whether it be on the TV, the phone, the laptop, and when they go out to watch comedy, just they want a break, man. And what I'm doing is I'm giving them a a break. I'm laughing. I'm being self-deprecating. I'm talking about my family. I've always said whatever the president is doing is not as funny as what my father's doing. So I kind of stick to kind of family uh and observational humor and and politics is something that I feel like if you start talking about in a way kind of splits the audience and it's just really not my interest. I'm not really interested so much in what's going on with politics. So my passion lies with my family and and and and that's what I talk about. Totally. Sebastian, I got to ask you. Did you see the viral clip? I think he reposted it actually from Saturday Night Live Marcelo Hernandez doing the Sebastian Maniscalo. This guy, he taught me everything I know. That's right. You know, ever since we were two kids at summer camp, back when we would be playing tennis, a shooting basketball, we used to love to swim. We were swimming. First of all, how did he do? But also, how did you react when you first saw it go on Saturday Night Live? Well, he asked me on Thursday to be a part of it. So, I couldn't because I was doing a show. So, when I first saw it, I was I was blown away. I really like Marcelo. He's a great great comedian. And uh I it was very flattering to see that on Saturday Night Live. You know, I got so many calls like, "You made it. You were on Saturday Night Live." And I'm like, "I've been doing this for 27 years, but it took Saturday Night Live to uh do a spoof on me for people to uh to say that I made it." So, I thought it was really really great and uh the exaggerated movements and whatnot. It was it was funny. I I really enjoyed it. How do you think he did? I feel like he clocked great, man. I mean, I think he did better than I did. I mean, this guy was uh doing jumps and splits and stuff that I wish I could do. Uh but uh yeah, man. I I I really enjoyed it. Hopefully, I'll get a I never even hosted the show. So, you never even hosted it. So, I'm making a plea here. Please, Lauren, have me on the show. Uh, and I would love to do a skit with Marcelo. Sebastian Manaskcalo, thank you so much for joining us, man. Appreciate you. Thank you. It ain't right is streaming on Hulu starting this Friday, November 21st.

key_facts: Sebastian Maniscalo is a comedian, actor, and podcast host.
His tour titled 'It Ain't Right' is selling out across the United States.
His comedy special 'It Ain't Right' begins streaming on Hulu on Friday, November 21st.
The special was filmed at the United Center in Chicago.
This is Maniscalo's second comedy special filmed in Chicago.
Maniscalo is 52 years old and has two children aged six and eight.
He identifies as an older father due to his age and parenting responsibilities.
He experiences physical discomfort from touring, including knee pain requiring icing.
Maniscalo performs observational humor centered on everyday absurdities.
He avoids political topics in his comedy material.
He believes audiences seek a break from politics when attending comedy shows.
He focuses on family life and self-deprecating humor instead of controversial issues.
Maniscalo grew up in Chicago, where he developed his comedic style.
Chicago’s culture includes sarcasm and playful mockery among friends.
His family attended the filming of his special in Chicago.
His father, mother, and children were present during the performance.
Marcelo Hernandez performed a parody of Maniscalo on Saturday Night Live.
Maniscalo was asked to participate in the SNL sketch but could not attend due to prior commitments.
He was surprised and flattered by the SNL parody of him.
He received numerous calls congratulating him after the SNL clip went viral.
He expressed admiration for Marcelo Hernandez’s comedic timing and physical performance.
He hopes to host Saturday Night Live in the future.
He would like to do a skit with Marcelo Hernandez on SNL.
Maniscalo considers Marcelo Hernandez a mentor figure from childhood summer camp days.
They bonded over shared activities like tennis, basketball, and swimming.
key_opinions: Maniscalo finds it distracting when people wear Invisalign during the day.
He believes Invisalign should only be worn at night.
He feels uncomfortable focusing on saliva trapped between teeth and aligners.
He enjoys performing in familiar environments like his hometown of Chicago.
He values the camaraderie and teasing culture among his Chicago friends.
He thinks comedians should avoid political content to maintain audience unity.
He believes comedy should offer a mental escape from real-world stressors.
He feels that personal stories about family are more relatable than politics.
He views his own father’s behavior as funnier than current political figures.
He believes Marcelo Hernandez did a better job than he could have in the SNL sketch.
He admires Marcelo’s physical comedy and exaggerated movements.
He sees being featured on SNL as validation of his career success.
He feels that recognition from SNL is meaningful despite his long career.
He believes hosting SNL would be a major career milestone.
He wants to collaborate with Marcelo Hernandez on a future SNL sketch.
key_datapoints: The comedy special 'It Ain't Right' streams on Hulu starting Friday, November 21st.
He has a six-year-old and an eight-year-old child.
He performed the special at the United Center in Chicago.
He has been performing comedy professionally for 27 years.
He was unable to participate in the SNL sketch due to a prior show commitment.
The SNL parody of him went viral and received widespread attention.
He received multiple calls from fans saying he had 'made it' after the SNL appearance.
He described the SNL sketch as humorous and well-executed.
He mentioned he wishes he could perform jumps and splits like Marcelo Hernandez.
He noted that his knees require icing at the end of each day.
He estimated the amount of bending he does during performances causes physical strain.
He stated he has never hosted Saturday Night Live.
He expressed interest in hosting SNL in the future.
He cited Marcelo Hernandez’s performance as superior to his own.
